Text.valUnicode: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}{\f1\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}{\f2\fmodern\fprq1\fcharset0 Courier;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;\red255\green0\blue128;\red0\green0\blue255;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.15.1515;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\cf1\b\f0\fs20 Once the \cf2 JCreate()\cf1 executes, you can use the Java class in your Magic program by using \cf2 JCall()\cf1 . In this example, the four functions of the calculator can be used.\par \par To use the \cf2 JCall()\cf1 function:\par \par 1. Instantiate the class, using \cf2 JCreate()\cf1 .\par \par 2. Specify the\i\f1 digital signature\i0\f0 of the class. In this instance, the signature for all four functions is: \par \par \cf3\f2 (II)I\cf1\f0\par \par where the first two '\cf3\f2 I\cf1\f0 's represent the two integer arguments, and the last '\cf3\f2 I\cf1\f0 ' represents the integer being returned.\par \par 3. Specify the method arguments. In this example there are two arguments to each function. Magic will handle some of the conversion, so for example you don't have to worry about whether the 'numeric' is actually an integer or a float.\par }
